introduction.eng:
Before we begin to guide you to engage more in activities you enjoy and are important to you, it is important to explain the mechanisms behind bad feelings and what fuels them. In other words:Why we feel bad, or with no energy to do things we like that are important to us.
Why it is hard to â€œget out of itâ€ and simply begin to be active.

section_text_1.eng:
Experts agree that when something bad happens to us or to people who are important to us, the chances it will makes us feel bad depends on three things:


1.    Our Thoughts - How are we explaining what happened? How do we think about ourselves?
2.    Our activity level â€“ Which types of activities are we doing each day? Did we stop doing things that we liked?
3.    Our physical state â€“ How much â€œenergyâ€ do we feel we have? Do we sleep and eat regulary? 

Letâ€™s see the following two stories

section_text_2.eng:
Mina is an experienced 26-year-old facilitator. Being a facilitator is both rewarding and hard. Things got complicated when the funder asked to run groups  with 25 families. Soon Mina began to think that she is not good enough. Every negative thing that happened in the group became a piece of evidence. 
Mina decided to put more effort into her work and stay longer with any parent who needed her. She finished her working days very tired. When she returned home. she didnâ€™t feel like doing anything â€“ just to be alone, and started to cancel meetings with friends and reject their invitations. 
In the beginning, staying at home and simply resting seemed like a good idea, but very quickly it started to be a routine. Eventually, her friends almost stopped inviting her. â€œeven her friends donâ€™t care about me anymoreâ€, she said. 
The more negative things and thoughts Mina experienced, the less active she became. although she went to bed early, she had a hard time sleeping because she was worried about the next day with the group. Because of it, she started every day more exhausted than the day before. 
Soon, her coacher realized that things are not the same as they were. She told them that she felt she is not the person she used to be.

Joyce explained it to herself as a sensible consequence of handling so many families. â€˜I only have limited time and I try your best. Funder targets are beyond my controlâ€™â€™, she said to herself.
When she succeeded to overcome a challenge she complimented herself: â€˜â€™It means that Iâ€™m still a good facilitatorâ€™â€™.  
Joyce finished her working days very tired. When she returned home, she collapsed onto her bed. But she decided to not give up on activities she liked and valued. She called her friends and said: â€œIâ€™m really tired lately. Because I still want to meet, can we meet at my house for a quick coffee?â€.  Her friends agreed to this change and continued to be in touch with her. â€œHow blessed Iâ€™m for having supportive friendsâ€, she told herself. 
The more negative things Joyce experienced at work, the more  joyful and meaningful activities, even those really short ones, gave her power. â€œDoing the things I like is like a backup batteryâ€, she said to one of her friends. 
Every day when she went to bed, she thought about the next session. â€œIt wonâ€™t be easy, but I know what to do. I coped very well during the last weeksâ€, she said to herself. After a good night of sleep, she felt refreshed, and had the energy for all of her activities during the day.

section_text_6.eng:
As you can see, both Mina and Joyce coped with a similar situation â€“ work-related distress. 
ğŸ˜Ÿ For Mina, the distress caused negative thoughts..This made her have less and less energy and motivation. which, in turn, made her feel more distressed.

section_text_2.eng: If participants are sharing vulnerable experiences, you have managed to create a safe space and a place of healing for them. They may have been carrying this pain by themselves for a long time.

section_text_5.eng: Even if you cannot â€˜solveâ€™ an issue during the session or after the session, there is still a lot of power in giving participants the space to share, as the group will bear witness to the pain experienced. section_title_1.eng: Parents do not feel comfortable talking with their teen

section_text_1.eng:
Parents may not be used to spending time with their teens and discussing together. Let them know it is normal to feel uncomfortable at first.

Explore the benefits of spending 1-on-1 time together. Emphasise that that is how parents and teens build trust and confidence to talk about more challenging topics and deal with difficult situations together.

Help parents think about their own past and about what they would have loved to discuss with their own parents. 

Explore the realities and risks that teens need to navigate, and ask what role parents should take: â€œIn our society, do these things happen? How much knowledge do our teens have and what risks do they run? How can we help them?â€ 

Explore the consequences of parents and teens not talking about difficult topics: â€œIf parents and teens do not talk about these topics, where will teens get this information?â€ Explore how these sources may give inaccurate or incomplete information and what the consequences are.

section_title_2.eng: Teens do not feel comfortable talking with their parents

section_text_2.eng:
Teens are often not used to spending time with their parents and discussing together. Emphasise that it is normal to feel uncomfortable at first. 

Explore the benefits of spending 1-on-1 time together. Emphasise that that is how parents and teens build trust and confidence to talk about more challenging topics and deal with difficult situations together.

Help teens understand that they also have a responsibility, now that they are not young children anymore. Their parents cannot read their minds, so they will need to learn how to share their feelings and experiences with their parents - even when the parent does not ask for this.

Emphasise that the group is a safe space. Remind them of the ground rules that every opinion is valuable and respected. 

Whenever one of the teenagers shares, make sure to praise their contributions explicitly. This will encourage other teens to also open up more.

title.eng: I donâ€™t know how to handle participants with special needs

introduction.eng: Know your participants before your group sessions. Be observant during recruitment to pick up on any specific needs your participants may have.

section_text_1.eng:
Be creative during sessions! Use pictures, drawings, and role-plays to show what you are trying to communicate. 

For example, when creating ground rules, you can draw a clock for time-keeping. 

When writing on the flipchart, use simple language and recap what was said.

Teens are more likely to be able to read and write and can often assist their caregivers during activities like budgeting.

It can feel embarrassing for participants to not be able to write. If you see participants are reluctant to sign the attendance register, agree on a good solution with your supervisor (e.g. you can tick attendance).

section_title_2.eng: Participants cannot participate in an activity because of their disability

section_text_2.eng:
Try to make every activity accessible for all! 

Be observant of any challenges participants may experience and find creative solutions. Encourage participants to participate to the best of their ability. 

If a participant struggles to stand during an activity, let them sit down and give verbal input. 

Involve the group as needed. For example, if someone struggles to hear, other participants can speak louder or you can sit next to them to recap what is being said.

rows.title: Group Facilitation

title.eng: Group Facilitation

introduction.eng:
* Good news! Almost every challenge you encounter as a facilitator can be resolved using the facilitation skills you learned during your training. 
* Whatever the challenge is, be positive and encouraging to make everyone feel welcome, valued and supported as equal members of the group. 
* Remind participants of the ground rules you created together, whenever needed. As a group, you set the boundaries to make your group work well! 
* Invite participants to identify their own solutions. You can guide them by asking how a situation makes them feel and by exploring the (possible) consequences of a behaviour or proposed solution. 
* Speak from your heart and in your own words, based on your great HHPP knowledge. This creates the safe space that is needed for everyone to work together well.
You are the expert!

section_title_1.eng: Group discussions are taking too long

section_text_1.eng:
* After small group discussions, select only a few participants (not all) to share their experiences. Stop once you have heard the learning points you are looking for.
* As soon as participants have shared those answers, summarise the key learnings and move to the next question.
* If participants struggle to get to the required learning points, simplify the question to ease understanding and link the question to participantsâ€™ personal experience (e.g. â€œIf this happened to you, how would you/your teen feel?â€). 
* Simplify and/or translate words that may be difficult to understand. 
* Know your group: If your group loves to engage in specific discussions, frame the discussion in advance (e.g. â€œI know this discussion will be so exciting. If you donâ€™t get a chance to share now, there will be more opportunitiesâ€). 
* Work together as co-facilitators. Plan together and help your co-facilitator keep track of time - if they go over time, signal to them discreetly that it is time to move to the next activity.

title.eng: Participants have a disagreement with each other

introduction.eng:
Stay neutral. Do not take sides in the discussion: 
1. Remind participants of the ground rules they agreed on (everyoneâ€™s opinion and experience is welcome, it is okay for people to have different views, raise your hand before sharing).

introduction.eng:

- **Identify possible solutions** â€œWhat do you think is the right thing to do for the person who shared the information?â€ (e.g., apologise)
- **Accept the answer** "Thank you very much. If you shared someoneâ€™s private information, please take the time to apologise to them.â€ 
- **Thank participants for sharing and emphasise also what CAN be shared** â€œThank you everyone for your contributions, and just remember, you can share all the skills and songs that we learn, but letâ€™s keep personal information in this safe space.â€
- **End discussion with an energiser** to bring back positive energy to the space, before continuing with your session.  
   
If the situation persists, have a separate 1-on-1 conversation with the participants involved.

rows.title: Initial home visit

title.eng: Initial home visit

introduction.eng: The first home visit helps you understand the family's needs and set realistic expectations. It also lets families learn about the program, ask questions, and share concerns. This makes sure the program is a journey for the whole family.

sections_title.eng: What should I do during the home visit?

section_text_1.eng:
Try to get as much as information as possible about the household, for example: Who lives in the house?
* Who is the main caregiver?
* How many children and teens are there?
* Who are the main caregivers?
* What are caregiversâ€™ professions?
* Which challenges are they facing as a family?
* What support or other programmes are available to them? 
* Which challenges can prevent them from attending the sessions on a weekly basis?

section_text_2.eng:
* It is important that each family sets one goal they want to achieve as part of the programme. Help them to set a goal which will be (1) realistic, (2) positive and (3) actionable.
* Realistic â€“ Based on your experience, can it be achieved within 9 weeks? If not, help the parent to think about a more modest goal.
* Positive â€“ Goals should be rephrased from negative language (â€œI want my teen to stop being selfishâ€) to positive language (â€œI want to get more help with house chores.â€)
* Parent-focused - Explore how the parent can contribute to achieving this goal

section_text_3.eng:
Ask participants what they want to achieve during the program. If their goal is negative, help them turn it into a positive one. Make sure the goals can be reached within 14 weeks, and rephrase them if needed.
**Parent:** I want to see my child go to University.**Facilitator:** Your goal is to see your child go to university. Our programme is 9 weeks long. Will your child be able to go to university in 9 weeks from now? Is there a quicker goal that can help your child go to university?**Parent:** Yes, I can help my child so they improve their marks in school this semester.**Facilitator:** Great! So your goal can be *Get ideas on how to help my child to improve his marks in school this semester.*
 
Make the goals focused on what the individual can do, rather than what their parent or teen can do. "What steps can you take to achieve that goal?" (e.g., if your goal is for your child to listen, what actions can you take as a parent?)

section_text_4.eng:
* Aim to have all household members attend to boost collaboration throughout the program.
* Strive to make it a conversation rather than just a Q&A session.
* Employ facilitation skills such as acknowledging, connecting, and exploring to strengthen the bond between everyone involved.

rows.title: How to manage expectations

title.eng: How to manage expectations

introduction.eng: Parents may have different expectations from the group and from you as a facilitator. Unrealistic expectations can cause frustration and may lead them to leave the group. It's crucial to identify and address these expectations early on. Here's how:

section_text_1.eng:
* Some participants may expect certain things based on their experiences with other programs, like snacks or transportation. This could be especially true if they've used other services from our organisation before, which might raise their expectations.
* Certain questions in the pre-post survey might make participants think the program will provide material support, such as asking about missed meals in the last week. Make sure to clarify the survey's purpose: 
* Families might have misconceptions about the program that could stop them from joining or cause them to drop out. Common misunderstandings to address include:
  - "This program is only for 'bad' parents or children."
  - "This program is only for a specific group, like orphans."
  - "This program is only for female caregivers."

section_text_2.eng:
* Set HHPP apart
Explain that HHPP is different from past programs participants may have joined. Make it clear they won't receive material rewards for joining HHPP, but highlight the unique benefits it offers, without putting down other programs.
You can't control what others say to participants before the program starts. What you CAN control is what you share during home visits and group sessions.

* Believe in the program's value
Have confidence in the value HHPP brings to families. Remember, HHPP's long-term impact on parents, teens, and families is more valuable than temporary material rewards.

* Foster group ownership

rows.title: Home visits & phone calls

title.eng: Home visits & phone calls

introduction.eng:
* If participants miss a session or need extra help, it's crucial to catch them up so they can keep building their skills and stay engaged.
* HHPP prioritises building parents' skills first to create supportive family environments for teens. For follow-ups, it's most important that the **parent is present**. Teens and other family members can join if available.

sections_title.eng: How to make follow-ups a success:

section_text_1.eng: Brainstorm with participants by asking: "Some of our group have missed this session, what can we do to get everyone updated?" When ideas and suggested dates/times come from participants, it's more likely the solution will work well for them and they'll follow through.

section_text_2.eng:
* In HHPP, each participant is paired with a 'buddy'.
* A buddy can share what they learned in the session with their partner. Even if a home visit is scheduled afterward, a buddy's update can reduce the burden of your home visit and help keep everyone up to speed. 
* To avoid someone missing another session, you can prompt the buddy to remind their buddy of the upcoming session.

section_title_3.eng: Do a joint home visit catch-up

section_text_3.eng: When several participants miss a session, consider inviting them to a joint catch-up session at one of their homes. This is especially helpful when participants live closer to each other.

section_title_4.eng: Do a phone call or WhatsApp call

section_text_4.eng:
* If participants have phones, give them a call to catch them up on missed sessions.
* If they have a smartphone with WhatsApp, you can catch them up via a WhatsApp call (or even a conference call to include multiple participants).

section_title_5.eng: Meet participants at school or work

section_text_5.eng: * Sometimes it's tough to find parents or teenagers at home at convenient times. You can see if visiting them at their school or workplace (office, farm, etc.) is an option.

title.eng: Graduation ceremony

introduction.eng: At the final session, families are happy that they completed the programme and want to celebrate. You can celebrate at the end of the final session or organise a separate â€˜graduation ceremonyâ€™.

section_text_1.eng: It can be a great motivation for both parents and teens to receive a certificate of attendance at the end of the programme.

section_text_2.eng:
* Ask participants how THEY want to celebrate THEIR achievement! Work together with your group to come up with a plan for how you can organise a ceremony. 
* Participants can contribute anything within their means, like snacks, food, or decorations. They may even surprise you (and themselves) with what they can put together as a group!

section_text_3.eng:

* If you do not manage to get music (or set up a more elaborate celebration), that is also okay. Distributing the certificates and singing some of the songs your group learned will be an important and festive moment in itself!

section_text_4.eng:

Paper & crayons
Music for dance party

* 1-on-1 time shows that you value your teen

rows.title: Session 1: Common Challenges

title.eng: Session 1: Common Challenges

introduction.eng: Parents are struggling with 1-on-1 time. They either donâ€™t have enough time, feel awkward, or have too many teens competing for their attention and time.

section_title_1.eng: I did not have enough time

section_text_1.eng:
* It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. 

* Think of a time each day that you could spare 5 minutes. You can even make household chores into a game to do together.

section_title_2.eng: My teen did not want to spend time with me

section_text_2.eng:
* Teens often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. 

* You could watch or play on the gadget with them. 

* Caring about their interests is a great start!

* Once you begin spending time together, you can suggest another activity.

section_title_3.eng: My teen wanted to do things I felt uncomfortable about

section_text_3.eng:
* If your teen wants to do things that are too difficult for you to do, you could watch them.  

* You could describe what they are doing like a sports announcer.

* Praise them while they do it!

section_title_4.eng: "My teen chose a competitive activity. I won and then they got angry"

section_text_4.eng:
Competitive games can be hard for teens (and adults!) if they donâ€™t like losing. 

When they have calmed down, talk with your teen about what winning well and losing well might look like.

Suggest other activities that you can do to work together instead of against each other.

section_title_5.eng: All my children wanted 1-on-1 time at the same time

section_text_5.eng:
It can be difficult to spend 1-on-1 time with each child when you have more than one child. 

If possible, you can ask an adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend 1-on-1 time with one teen.

Think of when it would be easier to spend 1-on-1 time with each child. Perhaps later in the evening with your teen, after the others have gone to sleep.

introduction.eng: A Parent forgot to praise? Teens felt strange when praised? Parents used negative and not positive instructions? Here are some solutions to these frequent challenges:

section_title_1.eng: I forgot to praise my teen

section_text_1.eng:
* It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our teens. 

* Next time you spend 1-on-1 time with your teen, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. 

* You can even say, â€œThank you for spending time with me!â€

section_title_2.eng: My teen did not like it

section_text_2.eng:
* It happens - just be patient. 

* Make sure to keep spending time with your teen, so they will value your opinion more and more. 
* When your praise is genuine, you will see the benefits soon!

section_title_3.eng: My teen was surprised and felt suspicious

section_text_3.eng:
* Remember, it takes some time for your teen to get used to seeing you praise them. 

* The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!

section_title_4.eng: Myâ€¯teenagerâ€¯did not want to follow the instruction

section_text_4.eng:
* Our children need time to learn to follow instructions. 

* Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!

section_title_5.eng: I gave a negative instead of a positive instruction

section_text_5.eng:
* It takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions â€“ itâ€™s really worth trying again! 

* Think about the behaviour you would love to see your teen do more and think of positive ways to give that instruction!

section_title_6.eng: I shouted at myâ€¯teenâ€¯when they behaved negatively, instead of giving them a positive instruction for what theyâ€¯shouldâ€¯do.

section_text_6.eng:
* It is difficult to come up with instructions while we are still angry. 

* Try and find a time when you are calm to introduce a positive instruction to your teen.

title.eng: Session 3: Common Challenges

introduction.eng: Did a teen feel uncomfortable when their parent shared emotions? Did a parent struggle with sharing? Here is how you can respond:

section_title_1.eng: "Iâ€™m afraid my teen might think I am weak for sharing my emotions."

section_text_1.eng:
* Sharing your emotions sets an important example for your teen - even more when sharing difficult emotions! 

* It makes everyone in the family stronger, because it means you can understand and support each other better.

section_title_2.eng: I felt uncomfortable about naming specific difficult feelings.

section_text_2.eng:
* Being specific is not rude or insensitive - it really helps others to understand you clearly and this prevents confusion in the family. 

* Feelings like anger and stress are part of our lives. 

* When we feel angry and stressed we can better handle our emotions by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

section_title_3.eng: My teen felt uncomfortable when I shared my feelings.

section_text_3.eng:
* Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. 

* Give yourselves time to get used to it and keep showing a good example by observing and sharing your feelings. 

* Over time, your teen will learn to do the same, and they will feel even more loved and cared for!

section_title_4.eng: When I shared my emotions, my teen asked many questions, which made me uncomfortable.

section_text_4.eng:
* Sharing emotions helps your teen to be aware and learn to do the same. 

* You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. Itâ€™s up to you! 

* You can also choose to answer questions later by saying, â€œI am feeling angry/stressed now. Could you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight.â€

section_title_5.eng: I was too stressed or angry to try sharing my emotions â€“ I prefer to be alone when I feel like that.

section_text_5.eng:
* Itâ€™s okay to not want to share at that time. 

* Find some time to explain later, when you feel calmer, so that everyone can understand.
